title: Where does cinnamon come from? - Quora

response.answer_text: The ground spice and the curled “cinnamon sticks” that are commonly known as cinnamon are actually the dried inner bark of the Cassia tree which is a close cousin of true cinnamon (Cinnamon Verum). Most commercial cinnamon is of the Cassia variety (Cinnamon cassia.) If you were to find true Ceylonese cinnamon (you can buy it on Amazon) the flavor is more subtle and less pronounced than the cinnamon most people are used to. There are some chemical differences between the 2 varieties which may be worth noting. See: Ceylon vs. Cassia — Not All Cinnamon Is Created Equal See also: Cinnamon - Wikipedia

The bulk of the world's production (80-90%) comes from Sri Lanka, but the plant is native to Bangladesh, Malabar Coast of India and Burma. It is the inner bark of a small evergreen belonging to the Lauraceae family. Additional information can be found here. HowStuffWorks "Harvesting and Production of Cinnamon"

Cinnamon is the dried inner bark of the tree belonging to the family Lauraceae. There are many variations. Among them, four major variations are available in the market.
